title: When should '…' be used vs '--' when writing dialogue? - Quora

response.answer_text: Please note: I violate this rule myself (just so we understand each other): Strictly speaking, “three dots” (three periods) should be used only to indicate an omission in the middle of a quotation. Four dots (four periods) should be used for an omission that includes a period ending a sentence that also ends a quotation. A hyphen (-) is used for hyphenated expressions like “Governor-General,” and a dash (—) is used to signify an interruption. There are two ways in which three dots often are used that do not conform to the official rule. First, there are some distinguished newspaper columnists (including writers of sports and financial columns) who use three dots to separate short, unrelated items. “Gilda Gotrocks was back in town after an adventure in Rome… Operagoers say that the drinks served at intermission are weaker than ever… Shortstop Biff Buntling is buying a $3.5M condo across the street from the ballpark…” A San Francisco newspaper columnist named Herb Caen, of happy memory, won the Pulitzer Prize for Journalism after a lifetime of creating three-dot columns. Second, in reporting dialogue, writers of fiction may indicate that what a character is saying trails off by running three dots at the end. >> John sighed and said, “I long for another trip to the Riviera,” and Marsha answered softly, “I long for the days when we could do it justice…” >> “My story begins forty years ago,” he said, “in a cheap hotel near the waterfront…” We listened in rapt attention, because we knew it would be a long story. Since your question is about writing dialogue, I think that’s what you have in mind: trailing off. In my own writing, I use three dots to suggest that a statement or thought is trailing off, and I usually can get away with it.

When should "…" be used vs "--" when writing dialogue? Two hyphens in sequence ("--") are never used in published typography. They are used only to represent a long dash when the keyboard or input device does not have the capability to create a long dash. Instead of two hyphens, the long dash (“—”) is always used. Three dots in sequence (“…”) are a single character, known as an “ellipsis,” which means, roughly, “something has been omitted.”____________How To Use An Em Dash (—) https://www.lexico.com/grammar/dash-and-em-dash An em dash, or long dash, is used in pairs, to mark off information or ideas that are not essential to an understanding of the rest of the sentence, as in: “Thousands of children—like the girl in this photograph—have been left homeless.” It is used singly in place of a colon (“:”) to indicate that the following text is an explanation of what went before it. Example: “It is a simple premise and yet, at the same time, an article of faith—a faith that the future would be better than the past.” In neither case are spaces used before or after the dash. Ellipses | The Punctuation Guidehttps://www.thepunctuationguide.com/ellipses.html An ellipsis is a set of three periods (“...”) that indicate an omission in the text. An ellipsis can also be used to represent a trailing off of thought, as in “I was just thinking how … but that’s another story.” Note that an extra period is added when the ellipsis occurs at the end of a sentence, as in “I was thinking about it when I was interr ….”
